title: Docker container fails to start on ARM64 architecture
content:
When trying to run PlexNet in a Docker container on ARM64 systems (Apple Silicon Macs, Raspberry Pi, etc.), the container fails to start with the following error:

```
standard_init_linux.go:228: exec user process caused: exec format error
docker: Error response from daemon: OCI runtime create failed
```

Steps to reproduce:
1. Pull the latest Docker image
2. Run on ARM64 system
3. Container exits immediately with exec format error

Expected: Container should run on ARM64 systems
Actual: Container fails to start

This is blocking deployment on modern Apple Silicon Macs and ARM-based servers, which are becoming increasingly common.

System info:
- Docker version: 24.0.6
- Host OS: macOS Sonoma 14.1 (Apple Silicon)
- Image: plexnet/monitoring:latest

Please provide ARM64 builds or multi-arch support.
author: dev-arm64-user

comments.author: plexnet-bot
comments.content: Thanks for the report. This is a known issue with our current build pipeline. We're working on multi-arch Docker images.

comments.author: arm64-user-2
comments.content: Same issue here on Raspberry Pi 4. Would love to see ARM64 support!

title: Feature request: Prometheus metrics export
content:
It would be great to have native Prometheus metrics export capability for integration with existing monitoring stacks.

Use case: We're running a Kubernetes cluster with Prometheus/Grafana for centralized monitoring. Currently, we have to use custom exporters or scrape PlexNet's REST API, which is inefficient.

Requested metrics:
- Device status (up/down)
- Bandwidth utilization per interface
- Error rates and packet loss
- CPU/memory usage of monitored devices
- Custom alerts as Prometheus alerts

This would allow seamless integration with existing Prometheus-based monitoring setups.

Technical details:
- Expose metrics on `/metrics` endpoint
- Support Prometheus exposition format
- Include appropriate labels for device identification
- Configurable metrics collection interval
author: k8s-monitoring

comments.author: backend-team
comments.content: Great idea! This aligns with our roadmap for external integrations. Planning to implement this in Q1.

comments.author: prometheus-user
comments.content: This would be incredibly useful for our setup. Currently using custom scripts to export metrics.

comments.author: dev-community
comments.content: I'd be happy to contribute to this feature if you need help with the implementation.

title: High CPU usage when monitoring large networks (>1000 devices)
content:
When monitoring networks with more than 1000 devices, the PlexNet server process consumes excessive CPU resources, often pegging all available cores.

Performance degradation:
- CPU usage: 80-95% sustained
- Memory usage: 2-3GB additional
- SNMP polling becomes slow/unreliable
- Web interface becomes unresponsive

This appears to be related to inefficient polling algorithms or lack of connection pooling for SNMP requests.

Environment:
- Server: 16-core CPU, 32GB RAM
- Devices monitored: 1200 switches, routers, servers
- Polling interval: 60 seconds
- PlexNet version: 2.3.0

Workaround: Increased polling intervals, but this reduces monitoring effectiveness.

Need optimization for large-scale network monitoring.
author: enterprise-user

comments.author: performance-team
comments.content: We're aware of this scaling issue. Working on optimizing the polling mechanism and implementing connection pooling.

title: Add IPv6 support for network discovery
content:
This PR adds comprehensive IPv6 support to the network discovery module.

Changes include:
- IPv6 address parsing and validation
- ICMPv6 neighbor discovery
- IPv6 subnet scanning
- Dual-stack device detection
- IPv6-specific device identification

Testing performed:
- IPv6-only networks
- Dual-stack environments
- Various IPv6 address formats
- Performance comparison with IPv4-only discovery

This addresses the growing need for IPv6 network monitoring as enterprises transition to IPv6.

Breaking changes: None
Performance impact: Minimal (~5% increase in discovery time for dual-stack networks)

Closes #412 (IPv6 support request)
author: ipv6-contributor

comments.author: network-team
comments.content: Great work on this! The implementation looks solid. We'll review and test this week.

title: Security vulnerability: SQL injection in device search API
content:
I've discovered a SQL injection vulnerability in the device search API endpoint.

Vulnerable endpoint: `GET /api/devices/search?q={query}`

The query parameter is not properly sanitized before being used in SQL queries, allowing attackers to execute arbitrary SQL commands.

Proof of concept:
```
GET /api/devices/search?q='; DROP TABLE devices; --
```

This could allow:
- Data exfiltration
- Data manipulation
- Database destruction
- Privilege escalation

Affected versions: All versions prior to 2.3.2

Please patch this immediately and consider implementing prepared statements or proper input sanitization.

I recommend this be treated as a high-priority security issue.
author: security-researcher

comments.author: security-team
comments.content: Thank you for the responsible disclosure. We're investigating this immediately and will provide a fix ASAP.
